title: How do viruses jump from animals to humans? - Ben Longdon

multiple-choice.question: What happened to some attendees at a Maryland country fair in 2017?

options.label: A
options.text: They were diagnosed with a rare genetic disorder.

options.label: B
options.text: They were infected with swine flu after coming into contact with sick pigs.

options.label: C
options.text: They were exposed to a new strain of influenza.

options.label: D
options.text: They were diagnosed with a foodborne illness.

multiple-choice.question: What are the three stages that viruses must move through to survive and reproduce?

options.label: A
options.text: Contact, infection, and mutation.

options.label: B
options.text: Contact, infection and replication, and transmission.

options.label: C
options.text: Infection, replication, and dormancy.

options.label: D
options.text: Transmission, infection, and recovery.

multiple-choice.question: Why are viruses often unable to infect new species?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are too small to penetrate the host's cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the genetic dissimilarity between the two hosts is too great.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the virus is not contagious.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the host's immune system is too strong.

multiple-choice.question: What can increase the odds of a virus successfully infecting a new species?

options.label: A
options.text: Time and genetic similarity between the two hosts.

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of a vaccine.

options.label: C
options.text: The host's immune system.

options.label: D
options.text: The virus's ability to mutate.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it challenging for virologists to predict the next potential epidemic?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there is a lack of funding for research.

options.label: B
options.text: Because there is a huge diversity of viruses that are not yet understood.

options.label: C
options.text: Because viruses are not contagious.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the host's immune system is too strong.

multiple-choice.question: Why doesn't the moon's orbit result in a lunar and solar eclipse every month?

options.label: A
options.text: The moon's orbit is too slow.

options.label: B
options.text: The moon's orbit is too fast.

options.label: C
options.text: The moon's orbit is slightly tilted with respect to Earth's orbit around the Sun.

options.label: D
options.text: The moon's orbit is perfectly aligned with Earth's orbit around the Sun.

multiple-choice.question: What can be observed by paying attention to the moon's movement from night to night during mid-June?

options.label: A
options.text: The moon's orbit is perfectly circular.

options.label: B
options.text: The moon's orbit is slightly tilted with respect to Earth's orbit around the Sun.

options.label: C
options.text: The moon's orbit is identical to Earth's orbit around the Sun.

options.label: D
options.text: The moon's orbit is only visible through a telescope.

multiple-choice.question: Why is NASA planning to continue exploring the moon in the future?

options.label: A
options.text: To establish a permanent human settlement.

options.label: B
options.text: To search for signs of life.

options.label: C
options.text: To learn more about the moon's composition and geology.

options.label: D
options.text: To advance scientific knowledge and understanding.

title: How close are we to eradicating HIV? - Philip A. Chan

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal in the fight against HIV, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To cure the disease

options.label: B
options.text: To stop HIV from being transmitted until it fizzles out

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the number of new HIV infections by 50%

options.label: D
options.text: To improve healthcare systems worldwide

multiple-choice.question: What do antiretrovirals (ARVs) do to combat HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: They cure the disease

options.label: B
options.text: They block HIV's access into immune cells and stop the virus from replicating

options.label: C
options.text: They reduce the symptoms of HIV

options.label: D
options.text: They boost the immune system

multiple-choice.question: What is pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)?

options.label: A
options.text: A treatment for people with HIV

options.label: B
options.text: A preventative measure for people who don't have HIV but are at risk of contracting it

options.label: C
options.text: A cure for HIV

options.label: D
options.text: A vaccine against HIV

multiple-choice.question: What is the idea behind "Treatment as Prevention"?

options.label: A
options.text: To treat people with HIV with ARVs to reduce their symptoms

options.label: B
options.text: To treat people with HIV with ARVs to lower the virus level in their bodies until it becomes undetectable

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent people from contracting HIV in the first place

options.label: D
options.text: To cure HIV

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, how much investment is estimated to be needed per year to achieve a nearly 90% reduction in new HIV infections by 2030?

options.label: A
options.text: $10-20 billion

options.label: B
options.text: $20-30 billion

options.label: C
options.text: $30-40 billion

options.label: D
options.text: $40-50 billion

title: This one weird trick will help you spot clickbait - Jeff Leek and Lucy McGowan

multiple-choice.question: What is the main issue with the headline "Healthium reduces risk of heart disease"?

options.label: A
options.text: The study was conducted on a small sample size.

options.label: B
options.text: The study only measured Healthium's impact on levels of a particular kind of cholesterol, not its direct effect on heart disease.

options.label: C
options.text: The study was funded by a biased organization.

options.label: D
options.text: The study was conducted over a short period of time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with drawing conclusions from a small sample size, such as the study on chocolate and stress?

options.label: A
options.text: It is more expensive to conduct a larger study.

options.label: B
options.text: It is less likely that the sample will closely represent the target population as a whole.

options.label: C
options.text: It is more difficult to recruit participants for a larger study.

options.label: D
options.text: It is less accurate to measure the effects of chocolate on stress.

multiple-choice.question: Why might scientists run small studies despite the limitations?

options.label: A
options.text: To save money and resources.

options.label: B
options.text: To evaluate whether the results are promising enough to run a more comprehensive study.

options.label: C
options.text: To recruit specific participants that may be impossible to recruit in large numbers.

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C.

multiple-choice.question: What is one thing you would like to know before deciding if the headline "New drug prolongs lives of patients with rare disease" is justified?

options.label: A
options.text: The cost of the new drug.

options.label: B
options.text: The side effects of the new drug.

options.label: C
options.text: How much the drug prolonged the patients' lives.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of patients in the study.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to look at the original research behind a headline?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the scientific jargon used in the study.

options.label: B
options.text: To evaluate the credibility of the headline and the study's findings.

options.label: C
options.text: To learn more about the researchers and their qualifications.

options.label: D
options.text: To find more information about the topic.

title: The Opposites Game

multiple-choice.question: What is the "Opposites Game" played by the students in the poem?

options.label: A
options.text: A game where students try to come up with antonyms for a given word or phrase.

options.label: B
options.text: A game where students try to come up with synonyms for a given word or phrase.

options.label: C
options.text: A game where students try to solve a puzzle or riddle.

options.label: D
options.text: A game where students try to write a poem together.

multiple-choice.question: What is the initial phrase given to the students to find antonyms for?

options.label: A
options.text: "My life had stood a loaded gun"

options.label: B
options.text: "The opposite of a gun is a pillow"

options.label: C
options.text: "A flower is the opposite of a gun"

options.label: D
options.text: "The sound of a bell and the hearer"

multiple-choice.question: How do the students respond to the task of finding antonyms for the given phrase?

options.label: A
options.text: They all agree on a single answer.

options.label: B
options.text: They come up with a few different answers, but eventually agree on one.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a shouting match and come up with many different answers.

options.label: D
options.text: They refuse to play the game.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of the game, according to the poem?

options.label: A
options.text: The students all agree on a single answer.

options.label: B
options.text: The students learn that there is only one correct answer.

options.label: C
options.text: The students realize that there may be many different correct answers.

options.label: D
options.text: The students give up and stop playing the game.

multiple-choice.question: What is the final message or theme of the poem?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of finding a single, correct answer.

options.label: B
options.text: The value of competition and winning.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that there may be many different perspectives and answers.

options.label: D
options.text: The danger of playing games in the classroom.

title: Why should you read “The Master and Margarita”? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the central plot of Mikhail Bulgakov's novel "The Master and Margarita"?

options.label: A
options.text: The story of Jesus of Nazareth's crucifixion

options.label: B
options.text: A romance between two members of Moscow's literary elite

options.label: C
options.text: The Devil's staging of a magic show in Moscow

options.label: D
options.text: A historical account of the Stalinist period in the USSR

multiple-choice.question: What is the setting of the novel "The Master and Margarita"?

options.label: A
options.text: 1st century Jerusalem

options.label: B
options.text: Moscow during the 1930s

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: The Soviet Union during World War II

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the demonic character who presents himself as a foreign scholar invited to give a presentation on black magic?

options.label: A
options.text: Azazello

options.label: B
options.text: Koroviev

options.label: C
options.text: Woland

options.label: D
options.text: Behemoth

multiple-choice.question: Why was Bulgakov's novel "The Master and Margarita" not published during his lifetime?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was not finished

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was rejected by publishers

options.label: C
options.text: Because of censorship and the oppressive Stalinist regime

options.label: D
options.text: Because Bulgakov was not a well-known author

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the phrase "Manuscripts don't burn" in the novel?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a warning to authors to be careful what they write

options.label: B
options.text: It is a statement about the power of censorship

options.label: C
options.text: It is a message about the enduring nature of art and ideas

options.label: D
options.text: It is a phrase used by the demonic characters to confuse the citizens of Moscow

title: The lovable (and lethal) sea lion - Claire Simeone

multiple-choice.question: At what speeds can sea lions swim while hunting?

options.label: A
options.text: 1-5 miles per hour

options.label: B
options.text: 4-18 miles per hour

options.label: C
options.text: 10-25 miles per hour

options.label: D
options.text: 20-30 miles per hour

multiple-choice.question: How do sea lions cope with the mounting pressure while diving to great depths?

options.label: A
options.text: By expanding their rib cage and lungs

options.label: B
options.text: By collapsing their pliable rib cage and compressing their lungs

options.label: C
options.text: By slowing down their heart rate and redirecting blood flow

options.label: D
options.text: By using their whiskers to sense the pressure

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the shape of a sea lion's pupils?

options.label: A
options.text: They are circular

options.label: B
options.text: They are teardrop-shaped and can expand to 25 times their original size

options.label: C
options.text: They are rectangular

options.label: D
options.text: They are triangular

multiple-choice.question: What do sea lions use to sense the slim trails of moving water left by fish?

options.label: A
options.text: Their exceptional vision

options.label: B
options.text: Their sense of smell

options.label: C
options.text: Their whiskers (vibrissae)

options.label: D
options.text: Their hearing

multiple-choice.question: What is a major threat to sea lions due to climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: Habitat destruction

options.label: B
options.text: Toxic algae species that can trigger seizures and brain damage

options.label: C

options.label: D
